Introduction

Bedbugs (Cimex lectularius, Cimex hemipterus) are small parasitic insects that infest human dwellings and rely on blood meals for survival and reproduction.

Pathophysiology and risk factors



The bedbug life cycle includes 3 stages: egg, nymph, and adult.  Adult bedbugs have flat, red-brown bodies (

image 1
) and hide in clusters along the periphery and crevices of mattresses, bed frames, and surrounding structures.  Bedbugs are nocturnal and attracted to warmth and carbon dioxide, typically feeding while their host sleeps.  Bedbugs inject an anticoagulant while feeding, leaving a hemorrhagic punctum at the bite site.  A typical blood meal lasts 5-10 minutes, and adult bedbugs can survive for up to a year without feeding.



Bedbug infestations can occur in any environment but are common in areas with high population density.  Transmission occurs between colonized objects (eg, cushions, luggage) within a physical living space; human-to-human transmission is rare.



Therefore, risk factors for bedbug infestation include:



  • Living in multiunit housing (eg, apartments)

  • Purchasing preowned furniture or clothing

  • Traveling to regions where bedbug infestations are common

Clinical presentation



Bedbug bites are typically painless and located on exposed areas (eg, neck, arms).  Reactions to bedbug bites vary, and for some patients, the hemorrhagic punctum is the only evidence of a bite.  For others, a local inflammatory reaction occurs, causing a small, erythematous papule or wheal with a central hemorrhagic punctum; pruritus is common.  A linear series of bites with a "breakfast, lunch, and dinner" pattern (

image 2
) is characteristic but not always present.  Bedbug bites typically heal within a week, although new bites occur with repeated exposures.  Bedbugs are not known to transmit diseases.

Diagnosis



Diagnosis of bedbug infestation is primarily clinical and based on the characteristic appearance of the bites.  Direct visualization of live bedbugs or their cast skins, eggs, or fecal stains confirms the diagnosis.  Patients may also provide a history of recent travel or exposure to infested environments, including symptomatic household contacts.

Differential diagnosis



The differential diagnosis of bedbug infestation (

table 1
) includes the following:



  • Chiggers:  small mites that live outdoors (eg, grassy fields) and cause intensely pruritic, erythematous papules on exposed areas (eg, ankles, waistline)

  • Scabies:  small mites that cause intensely pruritic, erythematous papules, often with burrows (fine, serpiginous lines), along intertriginous areas (eg, web spaces, axillae, buttocks)

  • Lice:  infestation that causes widespread pruritus of the affected area (eg, scalp, body, pubic area) with visible, live lice

Management



Management of bedbug infestation involves both pharmacological and nonpharmacological measures as follows:



  • Pharmacological measures:  Topical corticosteroids and/or oral antihistamines may be required for symptomatic relief until the bites heal.

  • Nonpharmacological measures:  Definitive treatment requires eradication of bedbugs and their eggs with use of insecticides and laundering with high heat.



To prevent bedbug infestation, travelers should carefully inspect bedding and store luggage on racks away from the bed.  In addition, preowned furniture and clothing should be inspected and laundered before use.

Prognosis



The prognosis for bedbug infestations is generally favorable with prompt diagnosis and eradication of the infestation.  Rarely, pruritus can lead to excessive scratching, secondary bacterial infection, and scarring.

Summary



Bedbugs are small parasitic insects that infest human dwellings and rely on blood meals for survival and reproduction.  Bedbug bites present with small, erythematous papules or wheals with a central hemorrhagic punctum in a linear pattern on exposed areas.  Diagnosis is clinical, with direct visualization of the insects for confirmation.  Management is supportive, and eradication of the infestation is definitive.
